data.text: Introduction
1.1. Passwords are an important aspect of computer security. They are the front line of protection for user accounts.

1.2. A poorly chosen password may result in the compromise of the Trust's entire information network, as such everyone is responsible for taking the appropriate steps to select and secure their passwords.
1.3. Password enforcement is balance between making a password difficult to guess but easy to remember.
Scope
2.1. This policy defines the standards for the creation of strong passwords, the protection of those passwords, and the frequency of change.
2.2. The Computer Misuse Act was passed by Parliament in 1990, which recognises the following offences:
Unauthorised access to computer material
Unauthorised access with intent to commit or facilitate a crime
Unauthorised modification of computer material
Making, supplying or obtaining anything which can be used in computer misuse offences
2.3. It is therefore important to note that misuse of computers is a criminal act and may result in prosecution.

2.4. This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.
Definitions and Terminology

table_items.text: This should be in reference to the individual Trust that the employee is employed by. Trusts refereed to include Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.
This refers to the Mid Essex, Southend & Basildon Trusts as they are starting to come together to form a Group model of service delivery. Also sometimes referred to as the MSB Group.
Access to information assets and/or Trust IT Systems

Throughout this document the term e-mail is taken to include any form of electronic text based communication used in the conduct of Trust business e.g. instant messaging solutions, approved Webmail systems etc.

Person Identifiable Information / Person Identifiable Data / Personal Confidential Data. One or more pieces of information that relate to an individual, who can be identified from those pieces of information or identified by combining those pieces of information with other information that is likely to be available. The individuals concerned may be patients, staff, contractors or members of the public.

Vicarious liability is a form of secondary liability where a person or organisation is liable for the acts of another. An employer can be legally responsible for the actions or omissions of their employees in the course of their employment. The employer is legally responsible unless it can be shown that 'reasonable steps' have been made to reduce this liability.
Outlook Web Access – a means of accessing the Trust E-mail system from the Internet remotely (i.e. not on Trust premises and not the computer network)
A Microsoft technology enabling Exchange email to be configured on a mobile device using the native device email client.

data.text: Roles & Responsibilities
4.1. Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1. Digital Services Governance Group – to review policies and recommend submission for group approval.
4.1.2. Information Governance Committee – to review any instances of non- compliance to stated policy.
4.1.3. Joint Document Management Group – to ratify polices
4.2. Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1. Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO)  – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.2. Caldicott Guardian  – Board appointed Site Director for each Trust is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PCD processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PCD.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PCD where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
4.2.3. Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for development and updating of Digital Services Policies.
4.2.4. Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for information governance.
4.2.5. Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
4.2.6. Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Policy Requirements

5.1. All computer accounts must be password protected to help maintain the confidentiality and integrity of electronic data as well as to help protect the Trust's computing resources and infrastructure.

5.2. This policy establishes a minimum standard for creation of strong passwords, the protection of those passwords, and the frequency of change. Where an IT system allows, the following protocols need to be adhered to:
5.2.1. Password History Users should not use any of the  previously used passwords.
5.2.2. Maximum Password Age Users should change their password after a maximum of 45 days.
5.2.3. Minimum Password Length Users are required to use a password that is a minimum length of 8 characters.
5.2.4. Password Complexity
Users are encouraged to use passwords that contain characters from three of the following categories:
Uppercase letters of European languages (A through Z, with diacritic marks, Greek and Cyrillic characters)
Lowercase letters of European languages (a through z, sharp-s, with diacritic marks, Greek and Cyrillic characters)
Base 10 digits (0 through 9)
Non-alphanumeric characters (special characters), (~!@#$%^&*_- += |\(){}[]:;"'<>,.?/) Currency symbols such as the Euro or British Pound are not counted as special characters for this policy setting.
Any Unicode character that is categorized as an alphabetic character but is not uppercase or lowercase. This includes Unicode characters from Asian languages.
5.3. A recommended technique for choosing passwords which are harder for others to crack but easier for you to remember is choosing a short sentence or phrase which makes sense to you, for example:
I eat Chinese food – Ieatchinesefood Spanish holidays - Spanishholidays

5.4. There are many other  ways to mix the characters, for example you could choose to always swap some letters for numbers or vice versa e.g.: the letter O for the number 0, the letter A for the number 4 or the letter S for the number 5 or the $ sign. For example:
I eat Chinese food – 1eatChinesefood! Spanish holidays – @Spanishholiday5

5.5. Do not use the same password for Trust accounts as for other access (e.g. personal ISP account, personal webmail, etc.). Where possible, don't use the same password for various Trust access needs. For example, select one password for the patient records system and a separate password for other IT systems.
Don't reveal a password to ANYONE
Don't attach a password to any machine e.g. password written on a label and stuck to a laptop or PC
Don't reveal a password in an email message
Don't talk about a password in front of others
Don't hint at the format of a password (e.g. "my family name")
Don't reveal a password on questionnaires or security forms
Don't share a password with family members
5.6. If someone demands a password, refer them to this document or have them contact someone from the IT Team or Information Governance.

5.7. Do not write passwords down and store them anywhere in your office. Do not store passwords in a file on ANY computer system, including any Trust or personal mobile computing devices, without encryption.

5.8. If an account or password is suspected to have been compromised, report the incident to the IT Helpdesk   support@meht.nhs.uk and the Information Governance Manager (ig@meht.nhs.uk) and change all passwords. Report the incident via Datix.

5.9. The use of Password cracking or recovery applications by unauthorised users is expressly forbidden. These applications may only be used by the Head of IT or the IT Operations Manager in order to facilitate security investigations. This will only be done with the written consent of the Chief Information Officer.
Training Requirements

6.1. No  specific  training  requirements  have  been  identified  however  staffs  are expected  to  ensure  that  they  keep  up  to  date  regarding  IG  and  IT/Cyber security update emails and messages published in staff circulars.
Monitoring & Audit
7.1. Non-Compliance
7.1.1. Do not share your Trust passwords with anyone including managers and Trust IT  staff.  All  passwords  are  to  be  treated  as  sensitive  confidential  Trust information.
7.1.2. Where there is a breach of this policy, the members of staff should report the breach as soon as possible using the Trust Incident Reporting System.

7.1.3. If a password is shared, the owner of the password will be held accountable for any information which is recorded or seen by using those credentials and will be subject to the Trust disciplinary policy which may result in dismissal.

7.1.4. Using another member of staff's password to illegally access and distribute person identifiable information will be treated as a serious incident and will be reported to the Information Commissioner's Office and may also be reported to the Police.
7.2. Monitoring
